question: Question_06_(c)
sols:
To begin with, recall that unitary matrices don't change the norm of a
vector, in particular $\|Ux\| = \|x\|$ and $\|V^*x\| = \|x\|$ for all
vectors \emph{x}. Using the definition of the matrix norm of \emph{A} we
find that

\begin{align*}
\|A\| &= \max_{\|x\| = 1} \|Ax\| \\
&= \max_{\|x\| = 1} \|U(\Sigma V^*x)\| \\
&= \max_{\|x\| = 1} \|\Sigma V^*x\| \\
&= \max_{\|y\| = 1} \|\Sigma y\| \\
&= \|\Sigma\|
\end{align*} where $\displaystyle y = V^* x$ satisfies
$\|y\| = \|V^* x\| = \|x\| = 1$. In other words, the matrices
$\displaystyle A$ and $\Sigma$ have the same norm. The norm of the
diagonal matrix $\Sigma$ is simply the largest absolute value of the its
diagonal entries. Therefore $\displaystyle 2 = \|\Sigma\| = \|A\|$.
hints:
Use the fact that \emph{U} and \emph{V} are unitary and hence do not
affect the norm of a vector.
